posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked:
This is the pattern that I made for the reversible bumpers my team has been making from scratch  for several years. It can be used for any size of U shaped bumpers. The instructions here are not very clear and are intended more as a general guide to how the pattern works, but if anyone is interested I can definitely write actual instructions on how to make the bumpers. I will also probably make a guide on how to make this pattern fit any bumper dimensions soon, and maybe make a version for 1 piece, L shaped, and 4 piece bumpers. I think it was also unclear in the instructions that you need to open the not sewn end in order to staple the bumpers. Bumpers Pattern 960×720 56.9 KB This picture is of our finished 2024 bumper fabric (I don’t have a picture of 2025), and the pattern makes a little more sense with it. 2024 Bumper Fabric 1865×1398 330 KB Note: These bumpers were made without any pattern, but the only major difference is the ends were made with bumper gaps in mind, so the pattern fits the current bumper rules better (they still worked fine, the ends were just a little weird to flip)

Bumpers Pattern 960×720 56.9 KB

Bumpers Pattern 960×720 56.9 KB

2024 Bumper Fabric 1865×1398 330 KB

2024 Bumper Fabric 1865×1398 330 KB

Finished 2024 Bumpers! 2024 Bumpers 1865×1398 285 KB

2024 Bumpers 1865×1398 285 KB

2024 Bumpers 1865×1398 285 KB

I also think our 2025 bumpers turned out much better, but these are the best pictures I have of them. 20250201_143149 1920×1448 245 KB 20250201_140339 1920×1432 233 KB I haven’t seen much information on making reversible bumpers around, so if anyone has any questions I would be happy to answer them!

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Yes please, I would love a guide on this.

posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked:
Here is a diagram for finding all of the dimensions you need: Bumpers Measurement Guide (1) 960×720 32.1 KB

Bumpers Measurement Guide (1) 960×720 32.1 KB

Bumpers Measurement Guide (1) 960×720 32.1 KB

A few notes: The seam allowance (G) is very important!! It is what gives you room to sew and it is where the staples to attach the fabric to your bumper backer go. It does not have to be exactly 2 inches, but you can always cut extra material off.

When we made our bumpers, we did not actually measure any of these dimensions. Instead, we used our built bumpers to trace each part onto the back of the fabric. We did this by tracing one face, then flipping the bumper to get the next part until the whole pattern was traced.

The angles on the bottom should be 45 degrees, but connecting the traced lengths of the inside (E + F) and outside (C + D) parts should get you this dimension.

posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked: I’m realizing how little sense this makes without context, so full explanation coming eventually (Google drawings may not have been the right choice for the diagrams)

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
There is really very little difference between regular and color change fabric patterns as long as we’re talking about sewn seams and not folding the extra fabric out of the way. The only differences are one extra seam down the middle at the fold, and decreasing the allowance from staples to 1/2” for sewing on one side.

For me, sheet metal CAD is by far the easiest way to make bumper fabric patterns, and if you’re doing color change bumpers I much prefer folding end to end rather than top to bottom.

posts.name: Kaden Morrison
posts.cooked: We were also able to make 1-piece reversible bumpers for this year, which are not as difficult to make with our instructions, if you want ours to help make a guide.
